reviewText:
Burned tires, bent bars, metal, fire, explosions, blood and guts everywhere.
This was hands down my favorite gore racing smashing game of my childhood, and playing and beating this was an unforgettable joyride.
As all old games, you have a few issues playing this on modern OSs. Mind your compatibility mode and do some googling to find advise. the game itself may run smoothly (like it did to me) but there are plenty fixes published for those who can't run it. (because hey, 99% of old games need a little something in order to run on win 7 and win xp platforms like they did on win 98s etc)

This game was obviously the awesome sequel of a major idea of a racing game where you can smash and disable your opponents instead of just winning the race first. Numerous games took after this franchise including the burnout games. The game has an awesome point awarding system where you can earn points by running over pedestrians, smashing opponents, destroying them, going through checkpoints and of course winning the race. The point system helps the player to buy the cars of fallen opponents (only when they're smashed to death) and use them onwards.

Meanwhile the variety of cars available in the game is ridiculous and pretty awesome. You get to drive vehicles from hot rods and rally cars to supercars and heavy duty trucks, all buffed up with blades and addons that make them look ready to kick ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.
All cars have a pretty hilarious way to be introduced, each unique and each with a driver that is one of a kind. Another cool thing is that you don't have to keep buying new cars if you don't want to since there's an upgrading system the evolves you car's armor, force and speed abilities as you play alloying you to stick with your favorite vehicle even by playing 99% of the game with it if you want to.

The game includes some nasty missions along with the races. Kind like boss battles. Some are really stressful and some are way too fun not to make you wanna replay them.

The graphics of the game are awesome of its release. You can smash your opponents' and your own vehicle in any way imaginable. Crash on them, throw them off cliffs, push them on explosive barrels, cut them in half, fry them explode them.
Use ridiculous powerups that make you throw flames or elecrify pedestrians, fart bombs from the back of your car and on your opponents behind you, make your car bounce, jump, turboboosted, undefeated or mess you up with drugs and alcohol effects.

The game is CRAZY and totally worth having fun with if you are into the genre.


Do mind that of course its not perfect. There are physics issues like the levels of handling on some cars, the was steering works on most, the sticky feeling of some walls of you crash on their side and other little details that for me didn't take out of the fun of the game at all.

Can't wait to play the sequel :D
Recommended? HELLZ YEAH! This is one of the most memorable and unique titles on racing gaming history.
Even if its really old, it is worth trying to play again!! And if you haven't ever played this, GET IT NOW!!! (or on the next special offer :P )

reviewText:
Carmageddon 2 is the first race‚Ä¶ cargame I ever played, and I have never had this much fun with a racer since.

Since this game is so old, I'll mostly mention the gameplay elements.

Race, Kill, Destroy
That's basically it, you do those 3 things, all the time, for fun, because you can.

Back then there already were soft-body physics, and though unrealistic and totally goofy, they are still fun, satisfying to see. Not only this, but they actively, and severely influence the gameplay itself, making you actually aim for certain ways to collide at times, just to cripple your opponent.

Though crashing into your opponents, racing across the creative maps, and killing all the peds you see is great fun by itself, this is even made better with the addition of tons of crazy and goofy powerups. Nowhere else can you send a car flying across the whole map using a coil spring, but here. (and maybe soon in the new Carmageddon too)

FIND ALL THE SECRETS!
Yes these maps were all designed to be explored, making them not only great and interesting battlegrounds, but also filled with tons and tons of secrets, powerups, and curiosities. Not only this, but most maps also have challenges ready for you, to unlock those secrets; ever tried a jumping puzzle with a car? (or 10ft truck?)

The Fun, The Crasy and the Annoying.
Now a lot of fun is ready for you as you already read, but there are also some warnings I‚Äôll have to give, especially regarding the physics engine.

Carmageddon has a great physics engine, but it doesn‚Äôt feel or play like one of a racegame; often you will feel like you‚Äôre actually floating on water, or flying through the air like you‚Äôre on the moon. (even without the lunar-gravity powerup) This by itself means‚Ä¶ DON‚ÄôT EXPECT FLUIENT RACING. Jumping puzzles are made easier because of this, but making tight corners, or any corners at all at high speeds, are impossible.

Be certain that you want a crazy, goofy, arcady game if you plan on buying it. This is not a real actual racegame, even if it is definitely a car game.

The glue that keeps the mess together.
The game has a simple GUI and should offer no problems at all. There are many quirky things to keep in mind like stats and cars to own and buy during and around the actual ‚Äòraces‚Äô, and the GUI certainly makes it easy to keep an eye on everything. The big flaws here lie with the controls settings, and the ‚Äòmap‚Äô.

The controls are by default mapped to the NUMPAD KEYS‚Ä¶ I know, a total WTF, and to make things worse, you can‚Äôt rebind them to any key you want‚Ä¶ meaning that you won‚Äôt be able to use arrow keys or WASD.  Trust me though, even if you could rebind them, you wouldn‚Äôt be instantly comfortable either due to the physics, so please forgive the game for this and give it a shot anyway. It won‚Äôt be long before you get used to it. I do however recommend that you try to rebind the other keys (repair, handbrake, use power, etc) to keys convenient to you. I know the game used to work with a steering wheel, but I am uncertain how it responds to the more modern ones. I do recommend using a steering wheel if you get the chance.

In regards to the map, this bugger is probably the only annoyance you‚Äôll have with the GUI. There is a minimap you can put on your screen, but initially it‚Äôll be in the center of the screen. You can fix that using Shift+arrow keys though, to move the lil bugger around. However, due to the low resolution of the game, it‚Äôs too small to be able to actually effectively use it as a minimap the way you‚Äôre probably used to. Apart from this there is a big map, which is a big overlay displaying the whole map at once. You can still drive though using a little portrait sized window‚Ä¶ a bit the opposite concept of the minimap.

The GUI has a little trick that helps with the map issues though, which basically locks on to targets and the next checkpoint. The minimap displays a line in that direction then, so you will at least be able to find the checkpoints and chase enemies, after looking at the big map on how to get there.

Sounds And Visuals
Now it‚Äôs 2014 so be gentle on this old-timer. Regardless I can already tell you that, although low quality, the sound is generally satisfying and applicable within the context. Scraping, bending and crashing metal sound very much as you‚Äôd want it to, as well as a very pleasant sound for breaking glass. Apart from this, Carmageddon offers you 4 tracks of heavy metal from Iron Maiden and 3 songs from Sentience‚Ä¶ which‚Ä¶ I don‚Äôt even know, but it sounds alright I guess, considering the game it is. So you‚Äôll probably want to play your own music the 2nd time you run the game, since you‚Äôll be hearing the same song over and over again otherwise.

Visually Carmageddon is very simplistic, and very dated. This however isn‚Äôt any problem within the context of the game, and in fact can be amusing at times. If you don‚Äôt mind the old graphics style, then you‚Äôll still find that artistically, the game is unique, entertaining and satestfying.

Personal Opinion
This game I have been playing since childhood, and has never let me down in entertaining me with some good old fun, even if it‚Äôs old.
Everybody has some game which is like a child to them, often old and forgotten by most of the population, and this is mine.

Notes
Have a Wacom tablet? I have, and with this game it‚Äôs been a pain in my buttocks. Often windows would suddenly start thinking my tablet is my main cursor input, causing many annoying bugs with my mouse. SOLLUTION: turn off the Wacom driver, either before or after, depending on how skilled  and knowledgeable you are with your keyboard.

I have never played this game online yet, so this entire review is based upon single-player experiences.

For all of you who don‚Äôt have enough fun yet with the game by itself, there are many cheatcodes available that allow you to do countless amounts of things. This game was made with FUN in mind.

Are you 15 to 25 years old? Good! This game will have exactly your level of humor if you know where and when to find it.

There apparently have been ports for this game, so you collectors, N64 owners or PS1 owners, you might be able to find this baby somewhere for those consoles as well.

This game has aliens, rideable rollercoasters, zoo animals, clowns, nuclear bombs, airplanes/jets, underwater driving, juvenile humor, rideable 10ft high trucks, rideable bobsleigh tracks, aircraft carriers, flamethrowers, tesla powers, rideable ski-jumps, underground mines, landmines, volcano‚Äôs, farmyard animals, the grand canyon, pyramids, helicopters and much much much more.

reviewText:
A casual, fun pedestrian smashing romp through Cities, an airport, a countryside village and more. Carpocalypse Now is a more fleshed out and greatly improved sequel with plenty of playtime, and even existing multiplayer for those willing to set it up. Racing is a minor part of this title and most of the fun comes from upgrading your vehicles and destroying your enemies.

Carmageddon 2 released at the height of video game censorship in the late 90s, and instead of benefiting from the widespread but controversial publicity like the first game, it suffered low sales in Germany, the UK and elsewhere where the law and market made it harder to promote. It was also mostly disliked by critics at the time who criticized early technical issues, and it took a long time before Carpocalypse Now was accepted as a great game and classic in its own right.

Following on from Carma 1 and the updated Splat Pack edition, Carmageddon 2 added a huge number of new tracks, powerups, enemy vehicles, abilities and more, all under a much better engine that, due to some intelligent designs, still runs well today despite aging graphics. For me, this was a game that never got the attention and player-base it deserved at the time, and remains a cult classic.

The development company SCi were basically a collection of 8 young programmers and developers with varying skill levels and very little experience in launching a game. They went with the principle that if it sounds like fun

reviewText:
Well... i've played this game almost 20 years ago on a steam powered ancient computer.
I was a kid, and back then i used to play only 3 games : Carmageddon 2, Duke 3d and Tomb Raider and obviously all the free shareware from 3d realms and Apogee.
In the '90s almost 1\3 of complete games were given free with shareware(at least on pc). Now you have to pay for hats and gun skins what a bag of pi.ss the gaming world has become lol, sorry for the OT

BTW wtf will you get in this game??Frenetic gameplay
Tons of the most various genres of powerups
A lot of cars
Funny tracks
Blood and guts everywhere
Awesome phisycs, handling and damage system (better than carmageddon reincarnation in my opinion)
Smashed cars and cunning stunts to the Max Damage (that's the name of the red skinned psycho)

To complete a race you can : smash all enemy cars to pieces OR kill every pedestrian OR race through checkpoints (adviced for noobs and annoying people only;)
There are also some bosses and other type of races that i will not spoiler now.
You can easily find mod packs that add tons of cars and tracks for this game on the net so...

Few simple things, but are the best recipe if you want some genuine fu.ckin fun.
It was funny then, and even now you can find out that very few games are like this.
This game alone should explain enough why the old school still rocks. (in the gaming but also in all the other fu.ckin things in my opinion;)
